text: Bottle from Craft Beer Cellar in Waterbury. Shared with Linh, Brendan, Dubra, Emily and Balazs. Pours a light amber body. Soft malt character with some pine and resin. Nice.

Had three during my sons second birthday party. Reddish copper pour. Nose is yeast and caramel. Tastes of peppery, rye, caramel, leaf pile, resin. Tastey and crisp. Listed as Red IPL on the bottle dont thinks its a variant though

pours unclear bright golden, orange (more than red) tint, with a nice reviving off-white cap offering some retention and lacing. strong and clean colombus - very spicy and piney; spicy and peppery cereals as well - specialty malts imparting toasted bread flavours; few nuts, hint of sweetness - raspberry jam/seeds; citrus, dill, clean yeast. moderate carbonation, light to medium body - oily; smooth, semi-sweet yet assertive grassy-spicy-piney finish. a clean hoppy amber with toasted bread and stone fruit lagering character. quite enjoyed!

Bottle from the brewery so hopefully pretty fresh. Pours a clear copper with a small white head that leaves nice lacing. Nose is of pine, slight peppery "something" (rye? alcohol?) and toasted cereals. Taste is of caramel, slight fruits and is moderately bitter. Slight bread/grainy flavors. Drying alcohol. Body is medium, carbonation moderately high and texture is oily. Overall a pretty solid red IPL, of course I havent have a lot of them but Jacks Abby always delivers something interesting regardless of the style!
Bottle from the brewery poured into shaker. Dark amber with lacy head, piney aroma upfront. Full body with mildly bitter hops taste and lingering finish.
Bottle from Beers of the World, Henrietta. Grape, resin, and spicy aroma. Resin and grape taste, crisp lagery finish, with high IBUs. Good.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2016 500th US rating. Pours a dark amber from a bottle, nose of pine, citrus and spicy hops. All rather balanced in the mouth as well, with some malt backbone there too. A slight sourness as well. Good beer.

Bottle, pours copper with small off white head. Smell is Munich and other malting, toast, caramel, and nice pine from the hops. Flavor is most of the same with tremendous balance of malt and hops. Some toast, grain, resinous pine and dark fruits. Really crushable.

Bottle after a run. Pours amber with a lacy, cream colored head. Aroma of pine upfront then citrusy and floral hops with toasted malts. Flavor the same with a nice amount of hops for this style. Average texture. The added hops make this lager better.
Lots of citrus and light malt. Some peel. Pours amber with ok head. Tangy finish. Tap at brewpub, where they are playing old school Beck and Im thinking my dad would like this place.

Bottled 11 05 15 purchased at TJ great Sandy colored substantial head loved at first sip. Opened a second one to be sure, excellent with a blue cheese and cracker. So good I decided to stay home and savor rather than go out to shop. Good job Jacks Abby, I will be sure to get over to brewpub to sample it on draft. Will go back to TJ to buy more to see if my Cicerone certified son agrees when he arrives for Tday

Sample on tap at the brewpub. Clear amber brown pour with thin white head. Aroma is malty, nutty, fruity notes, light peppery hop. Taste is sweet, malty, toasted and nutty. Palate is light bodied with good carbonation. Good.
Very thick, but not sticky... Tasty but not really my style, decent overall, but they make better.

Where and how:  b 355 ml.
Aroma hefty malt feel, tad creamy, hinted with pungent hop notes. Herbal with hint of peppery feel.
 Appearance :
Top: lighter beige white top. Well contrasting with its base.
Base: cloudy amber.
Palate :  medium bodied with very delicate carbonation.
Taste: earthy, woody malts. Slight forest wood like bitterness. Bit lifeless. At edges malt feels slightly underdeveloped.
 Other notes  small tweaks with body and carbonation would make this beer excellent.
Bottle from Debucas in Raynham, MA. Reddish orange pour with a soapy white head. Earthy, grassy, some pine, and a bit of staleness. Okay, but not really my style.

6 pack, February 2015Bright ruby-tinted amber body is clear and has a cornmeal colored head atop that is well-retained.Quite the aggressive aroma...Certainly very influenced by the columbus, with a good deal of acidic pine and sourdough-heavy munich malt. On the edges are some spicy, moderately grassy hop notes that smell delightful but are very dominated by the heavy pine and orange rind alpha acid assault. Possibly some alcohol in there too...Sadly, more of the same in the flavor. Jacks Abby seems to either want to bludgeon you with bitterness or leave it wholly absent; not much in between. This would have been a nice beer to tolerate some acidity, not that I really know why you are trying to get PNW high alpha hop character, especially the pine resin, in to a German-style dunkler bock. But at this rate, its just too much and takes over the beer. As well, the munich malt creates too much of the signature sourdough-like toastiness and its just all palate fatigue after the first few sips. Well-attenuated, with a soft, almost slick texture that becomes nearly creamy from the tight carbonation. Reminds me of Old Guardian, somewhat...
Copper/amber pour with tan head. Toffee/malty aroma. Taste is bitter and earthy hop up front. Earthy malt too. Some roast coffee flavors in the piney hop finish. Very tasty.

From the 12 fl. oz. bottle bottled 11/24/14. So it is a few months old. Medium reddish-amber pour with a small head. The aroma has a kind of perfume thing that I need to note. Otherwise more toward malts and fruity hops with a slight burnt sensation. The body is light to medium. The taste also has that perfume or cologne based maltiness with modest sweetness. Clean, crisp hop finish.

Tap at Roundhouse. Clear honey gold pour. Aroma is honey and malt with a bit of pine hops. Taste is round pleasant pine resin hops with smooth malty backbone. Palate is smooth. Carbonation fine. Not nearly as malty, luckily, as expected from a bock of this type. Cut through by the clean hoppy flavor. Nice. Would get again.

Draught at Roundhouse. Clear amber-orange with thin watery sudsy white head and fizzy legs. Smell is faint red malt. Taste is resinous and hoppy, some lightly spicy malt. Body is crisp, a little thin, small bit of carbonation. Taste has a nice balance; aroma and palate quite thin.
Dark copper colored body an off-white body. Spice and pine aroma. Medium bitterness. Mild sweet caramel. Clean to finish.

Got in a BIF from ZebraCakez. 12 ounce bottle into lager glass, bottled on 11/12/2014. Pours lightly hazy deep orange/copper color with a 1 finger dense and rocky light khaki head with great retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big grapefruit, lemon zest, orange peel, pine, herbal, floral, grass, light caramel, toasted bread, and herbal/grassy earthiness. Damn nice aromas with good complexity and balance of big citrus/pine hops and moderate bready malt notes; with good strength. Taste of big grapefruit, lemon zest, orange peel, pine, herbal, floral, grass, light caramel, toasted bread, and herbal/grassy earthiness. Fair amount of spicy herbal/pine bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, lemon/orange zest, pine, light caramel, toasted bread, and herbal/grassy earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Very nice complexity and balance of citrus/pine hops and moderate bready malt flavors; with a good malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Very clean on lager flavors with zero yeast ester notes present. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, crisp, and sticky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with zero warming present after the finish. Overall this is a damn nice hoppy amber lager. All around great complexity and balance of citrus/pine hops and moderate bready malt flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink for the ABV. A very enjoyable offering.

Most of what Jacks Abby Brewing tends to make are ales but fermented with lager yeast. In the case of Lashes Lager, it is supposedly a bock style (or Hopbock according to the label), though it is closer to what I would associate with an amber ale. And as an amber ale it works quite well, but as a bock it does not. Not that I grade to style, anyway, just that I really appreciate the flavor profile here.

I poured a 12oz bottle into a lager glass. It was bottled on 10/29/14 and cost $2.69 ($0.22 per ounce).

Appearance: Hazy shade of copper/amber/orange with plenty of visible carbonation. Pours to a large, white, soapy head which retains and laces quite well.

Smell: Sweet floral scent, like a bouquet of flowers. Hint of citrus.

Taste: Munich Malt is the only malt mentioned in the description and it definitely comes through right away. A slightly bready, perhaps toasty, malt character. Lightly sweet with an authentic grain taste to it. Theres a subtle floral and citrus hop character lurking in the background throughout the first half of the swig. On the backend the bitterness becomes quite prominent, though its still pretty tame compared to an IPA (but would be normal in an amber ale). Theres some spiciness right on the finish with a taste comparable to rye. Light orange citrus is noticeable, too. I do notice a slight astringency on the finish, which is a bit bracing at first, but easy to ignore. Overall, its a tasty, interesting and satisfying palette, though Im not sure why its marketed the way it is. I enjoyed it.

Drinkability: Lagers are supposed to be lighter, crisper, and more easy-drinking than ales and thats true of Lashes Lager. However, considering its a rather potent brew at 6.8% ABV, Im a little surprised there isnt more complexity and body. This is the kind of beer where having a sticky, chewy mouthfeel would actually be beneficial.

Bottle:
Cloudy, berry-brown with a small, off-white head.
Aroma is dark, caramel.
Taste is leafy bitter, caramel malt, fruit.
Tea-like, with a mild alcohol bitter.
Rather bland.
Bottle. Lactic toffee malt and mild astringent alcohol aroma. Amber with minimal head. Sweet toffee malt and lightly bitter weedy vegetal flavor. A bit harsh.

Thanks AFH! Pours a cloudy dark orange. no head. barely a carbonation sound when I uncapped it. Nose is a mild bitterness, some tree fruit and burnt sugar. Yeah, a sweet pine cone forward malty beer, very little yeast, some pumpernickel or gingerbread beer. finish is bitter.
Amber pour, off white head. Flavor and aroma both have floral, grassy, citrusy characters. Quite decent.

Tap. Pours a deep but clear brown with minimal head. Citrus hop aroma. Lots of hop flavor up front with a bit of grapefruit sourness that lingers. A little light on the carbonation, but it worked well with this beer. Very drinkable and excellent overall.

Look: Deep Amber with almost a hint of mango. Smooth malty taste with a light hop end to it. Very enjoyable.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle purchase at One Stop Market. I fell like a lot of people dont appreciate some of the old school German styles. This is a nicely hopped German bock that is under rated in my eyes. Dark Amber color with thin lasting head. Aroma is earthy malts, pine and toasted caramel malt.
The flavor has the essence of autumn throughout the sip. Earthy Munich malt that gives a dried leaves note upfront with a mild toasted grain and cracker like backbone. Mild hits of caramelized sugar. Before the beer becomes to sweet from the malt, a nice level of citrus and pine hops show in the backend of the sip to balance everything out. Moderate level of bitterness. I want to drink more after the bottle is empty and I really dare somebody to find me a better brew in this updated American version of this classic German style lager.  Very finely crafted.

Bottle from Table & VIne. Clear dark copper or light amber with lasting head and lace. Very mild aroma of caramel cake with mild pine hops. Sweet caramel malt with mild fruity bready sweetness. Mild dry bitterness fruity and one. Some cloying. Okay. Hard to make a good strong lager without cloying sweetness IMHO.

Bottle 12oz.
Pours amber with medium pale beige head. Good lacing. Aroma is of citrus, lemon, orange peel, some malt. Taste is of alcohol, bitterness, roasted malt, sugar, pine, fruits, faint caramel, citrus, some pepper. Palate: Medium body. Medium carbonation. Nice balance. Overall: Well this is very good. Fine.

Bottle (12 oz) bought @ Craft Beer Cellar Waterbury.

Appearance: Clear amber with a medium off-white head and little lacing. 

Aroma: Light spiciness, caramel, cereals and earthy hops.

Taste: Earthy/mineral with light spiciness, cereals, resinous notes and light caramel.

Palate: Medium body. Moderate carbonation. Honeyed texture. Clean. Mild lingering spicy finish. 

Overall: Super clean and easy to drink but lack of depth and no the among the most flavor Bock that I have tried so far.
Pours a funky hazy brown, light white head. Aroma is fresh bread, caramel, earth, old hop. Flavor is light sweet, earth, bitter hop, light pine. Med mouthfeel, pretty full. Ok
Bottle, pours dark, aroma is hoppy, and taste is bitter was a bit rough around the edges for me, not my favorite of their stuff.

Bottle at home. Pour is hazy brunt amber with a frothy cream-colored head and great lacing. Spicy hoppy, rye bread, caramelly, toffee, grassy, doughy, and cereal in the aroma. Taste is caramel, toasted bread, grassy, honey, spicy hops, and crackers with a crisp finish. Medium body with high carbonation. Decent bock.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle. The nose is pine, resinous, bread crust. The flavor is malt forward, bread crust, rich maltiness, the hops become noticeable in the finish with flavors of citrus and pine. This is a very interesting beer, I love the bready malt quality intermingling with the pine and citrus American hop notes.

Aroma: Bready, Garlic, Onions

Appearance: Amber/Reddish Hue, Passes Some Light, White Head Ring, Decent Lacing

Taste: Onions, Bready, Mild Garlic

Mouthfeel: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Drying

En fût. Pinte dégustée chez The Dirty Truth (Northampton, MA) au coût de 6,50$. Arôme: Légère odeur de caramel avec une pointe dhoublon. Apparence: La couleur est cuivrée. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle le verre. Saveur: Léger goût de caramel et de céréale avec une pointe dhoublon. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de céréale en arrière goût. (Rating #5524)
Bottle as shown. Pours a cloudy orange with small frothy white head that diminishes to nothing. The aroma is caramel, pine, and herbs. Medium mouthfeel with light caramel malt and wet biscuit. Good.
growler,red colour, medium mouthfeel. hoppy aroma,like ahoppy lager. a little chocolate. drinkable.

My Bottom Line:
Spicy hops and mild cereals evolve in a lean and drinkable body for a clean but forgettable pint of Dunkler Bock.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A veil of foam covers the clear amber.
-This lacks malt character for my tastes in the style. The Andechs we had side-by-side was much better defined for the same abv range and similar body.
-The chosen hops are harmonious with the grain bill, but tend to take it over flavor-wise.
-The mouthfeel is as slender as most Jacks Abby lagers.

On tap at The Dirty Truth.

Bottle: Large gradient from tinged amber all the way to deeper shades of copper, even with a hint of ruby in places; large, foamed-up & creamy light-beige head lots for a while & leaves great lacing behind. Aroma is packed with wet pine needles, dirty & earth-laden hops, leaves, a hint of bitter, white pepper covered citrus rind & a decent backbone of semi-sweet, toasted & borderline caramel-like malt. Very nice hop bite on the front end of each sip with strong notes of pine tree, earth, & obscure citrus. Lots of brash leaves, giving a strong pungency & really stinging the back-end of the tongue with bitterness. The Munich malt introduces a nice toasted cracker, biscuit-like sweetness & flavor, just shy of toffee, without growing too sweet. Clean finish, pine resin aftertaste with a lasting bitter bite. Definitely a different ("American") take on this style, very enjoyable overall.

Bottle. Pours clear reddish amber with a small off-white head that sticks around fairly well and laces nicely. Aroma is pine, citrus, dark bread, caramel. Flavor follows, light plus sweet, pine and citrus hops sitting on top of a bready pumpernickel malt base. Bock-IPA is the newest rate beer style? Pretty tasty one at that. Medium body, nice carbonation. A bit of heat apparent, which is surprising at 6.8%
amber pour, small cream colored head, moderate lacing. nose is bready, mild citrus. taste has solid bitterness, bread, caramel, pine, citrus. medium full body. pine hangs on the toungue.

12 oz. bottle. It pours clear copper color with a small off white head. The aroma has some dry, toasty Munich malt with some earthy, floral and lightly piney hops. The flavor is malty up front with toasted bread and hints of honey and brown sugar followed by a rather assertive floral, spicy hop character. It finishes dry and spicy bitter. Pretty full on the palate with good carbonation. Nice lager.
Copper pour, white head. Flavor is a really nice blend of malt and hops. So well balanced. Good bready notes, grapefruit peel, spicy hops, caramel. Nice.

Pours a medium golden with a boozy head. Aromas piney, spicey, citrus and slight toffee. Flavors piney, citrus, light florals,;medium spicey hops grass, grain/toffee. Aftertaste is surprisingly clean with only a light bitter aftertaste. Has all the appeal of a nice hoppy ipa with a backside of a crisp almost clean lager. I do Like this one. Mostly like and ipa with a lager-like back bone.

Pouts out a slight hazy copper/red with a tan head and looks just like an IPA. Good aromas of citrus and pine, but the spicy hops and relatively high alcohol content give it a flavor almost like a pepper beer. Lingering bitterness and biscuit flavors, but the lagering gives it a very clean profile. A little thin in the mouth, but it pairs well with brats.
Dark Amber golden pour with a thin white head that laces down. Nose is sharp citrus and pine. Smooth body, earthy malt, with a piney hop finish.

Une bouteille, merci Patrick. Un liquide cuivré avec une mousse beige. Un nez de houblon floral avec des notes légères de malt sucré. Une bouche qui se boit tout seul, floral encore une fois, une superbe amertume forte en finale. Un régal.

Single bottle from Julios. Pours out a clear light golden-amber with a nice frothy white head that settles to a thick lace. Nice floral-spice aromas. Flavor is very smooth. Good malt and hop balance. Finishes slightly nutty with some floral bitterness. Glad they are packing 6ers now. I may pick this up again soon.

Boostle from shelfie aroma. Pours a,beer with a large off white head. Aromas of shelf, lager, toasted nuts. Taste is caramel, toffee, low bitter, low hop. Not juicy. Semi sweet. Its pretty ok. Not great.

Bottle. Poured a nice dark orange, slightly brown. Definitely a nice fresh hop character. Earthy hops, for lack of a better term. Nice and smooth mouthfeel. Almost a little too hoppy for the style, if thats possible.

[Bottle (12oz)] Pours a deep orange-amber with a large lasting frothy off-white head. Minimal lacing. Aroma of spicy and piney hops, caramel malt and fruit. Fruity and hoppy flavour along with caramel malt, light vegetal notes and a long-ish moderate bitter finish. Medium bodied. Pretty good but it resembles no Bock Ive ever had.

Bottle. Pours a near clear amber with a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a good amount of musty and earthy grains with a hint of underlying sweetness. Flavor is similar with musty earthy grains up front with a bit of sweetness and crispness coming out in the finish.

Bottle @ home, sent via courtesy wale slaying of LOINESHAWN. Thanks. Pours a hazy dark reddish orange appearance with a cream colored head. Fairly spicy, piney hoppy, nutty, toasted malty aroma. Kind of nutty, woody herbal, a bit burnt grainy, spicy hoppy flavor. Decent but nothing like some of their other offerings just now.
Des malts riches et caramélisés avec une tranchante présence houblonnée en finale, un autre monstre de buvabilité pour Jacks Abby.

Poured from bottle into pint glass: Pours brown with a hint of red, has a one finger tan-ish head. Aroma of roasted munich malts, earth, and a hint of pine. Taste has a very strong malt characteristic but isnt as sweet as I was expecting. Its a very dry lager, which is great. Nicely balanced with the hops, its quite tasty!

Bottle in NH. Pours clear amber with a soft, creamy white head. The nose holds sweet fruits, berries and leaves. Medium sweet flavor with dried bread, grains, toasted brown sugar, leafy bitterness. Medium bodied with fine to average carbonation. Sweet finish with piney hops, more grainy bread, dry grass, dried berries. Very decent.

Une belle robe cuivrée. Une mousse peu tenace. Une dentelle étagée. Au nez, un jeu fabuleux de houblons terreux, fruités et résineux. Une longue trace maltée, légèrement parfumée par un caramel foncé et agréablement entourée par des arômes de cacao en poudre et de pain grillé. Dévidentes et dirrésistibles odeurs de fleurs comestibles et daromates. Du romarin ou quelque chose qui partage les mêmes molécules. Au goût, une recette élaborée pour ne pas déplaire à mes papilles. Des saveurs doranges, de citrons et de sapinage qui traversent une belle étendue maltée, construite sur la base de grains grillés et légèrement sucrés. En bouche, je perçois un corps assez svelte qui profite de ses bulles fines pour offrir une texture presque crémeuse. En finale, une aventure qui nest pas du tout maltée avec de longues notes botaniques et des fleurs qui me mordent avec intensité et allégresse. Tout compte fait, une proposition (singulière) qui me réconcilie linstant de quelques gorgées avec un style tellement inintéressant.
draft at Coles, Buffalo NY. Caramel malt heavy vienna lager like. Creamy body like a bock. Some piney notes, orange marmalade 7 heavy caramel maltiness. easy drinking, decent

Pours a perfect amber orange with a brilliant clarity and a stream of bubbles rising ot the top. A thick pillowy head of foam adorns the prettiest color beer I have seen in a long time. Leaves sheets of wet lace. Nose is bright with fruity and floral hops. A bit of subtle citrus and stone fruit quality. There si a rich deep malt in this that sports both grainy bread and a light brown sugar. Taste is handsome. Restrained and subtle hops lend a citrus twang to a very earthy grain that has a bit of baked sweetness on it. Tiny bit of resin to coat the throat and leave a rich aftertaste. Brown sugar, hop floral and a light hop spice that goes so well with the earthy and lightly sweet grain. The carbonation is a bit tingly and the hops give a seductive little sideways glance to this beer and they finish with the smallest bitter. 

Just fabulous. Hearty, rich, textured and full of flavor. The stone fruit in this is the surprise and the sensation. it softens the hop character to the point of luxury. It enhances the grain sweetness but doesnt overshadow it. It takes to the bit of hop spice and makes this beer dapper and a little bit sweet.
Tasterat the source. Pours orange brown with an off white head. Aroma is grassy. Tastes of pale malt and pine resin hop.

50cl bottle.  Large beige head atop crystal clear amber body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, some resin/pine, light bread, grapefruit/earthy, chocolate.  Taste is moderately sweet, bread, grapefruit, resin, some pine, chocolate.  Medium body, light stickiness.  Alcohol presence known but not overpowering.

Really good.  Like an American pale ale but a lager. A bit too bitter for me but I am not. Hop head. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500ml bottle in a lager glass.  Pours amber with a lacy, cream-colored head.  Aroma of citrusy and floral hops and some pale and toasted malts.  Flavor the same with a nice amount of hops for this style.  Average texture.  A pretty good beer for the style.

500mL bottle purchased from Learys for $3.30. To snifter it pours a rusty amber gold with a trim off-whitish fluffy head. Aggressive aromas of American hop pellets, krill oil, caraway seeds, lager yeast, pineapple syrup, moldy peaches (did you catch my music reference there?), burnt fabric and guava. Starts off a tad fruity and malty, with notes of piny and citrus hops, grapefruit zest, and green tea.  Honey, vitamins, yeast by swallow. Good beer. Perhaps a tad too much hop bitterness, but overall a pleasant experience, Im officially a fan of this brewery.

500mL bottle courtesy of radarsock.  Cheers, Ander!  Pours a mostly clear sunset amber with an off-white head.  Nose is light caramel and bread with some earthy hops.  Flavor follows- nice assertive malt character with hints of lager yeast and some sweetness among the light earthy and piney hops.  All in all a nice, medium-bodied Vienna.

Bottle from gn0sis. Pours a nice golden red with a fluffy, persistent white head. Big citrus and pine aroma. Taste is very hop forward, very fresh and bitter. Drinks like a hoppy red ale. Very well balanced.

Resinous IPA type aroma over faint caramel background. Copper color with lacy tan head. Bittersweet malt taste which is is mainly bitter with a striking, crisp sweet malt strip down the middle. Not caramel flavored, but something starchier. Definitely the strongest and bitterest vienna style lager around, an imperial version of that style. Good product continues to flow from the lager lovers.

Wow - this is like a sheep in wolfs clothing - more like an IPA than a Vienna style lager. Pours beautiful hazy crystal amber with a decent white head. The aroma brings decent sweet and somewhat tangy hops. The flavor brings some sweet hops and tangy malts as well, very decent for the style.

50cl bottle pours a clear, honey brown with some frothy white head.  Nose was inviting if not a little muddled, some lemon, citrus peel, grass, pine needles, a little malt, biscuit.  Flavor was nice too, sweet, malty, crackers, lemon, grass, a little lemon grass.  Medium, dry finish.  Well balanced.

Bottle.  Clear gold with some leg and head.  Aroma is	very nice combo of American pine, ripe tropical fruit and grassy, spicy character.   toasty grains done through. The flavor is very balanced with distinct hop and grains coming through. Great beer.  Cant wait for distro in NyC.

Poured from half liter bottle into lager glass. Thick, foamy white head over golden bronze, clear liquid. Head persisted for a while then dwindled to foamy rafts. Aroma was slightly hoppy, trace citrus, swee malt underneath. The flavor is clean, a little piney, a little floral, nice grapefruit bitterness. Sweet malty flavors underneath. Pretty well balanced. Went nicely with spicy chicken and salsa I was eating. Nice brew, even if it is named after some guys eye hair.
500ml bottle. Light golden pour with a white head and decent lacing. Hoppy aroma but the flavors were slightly more to the malt side. Nice refreshing well balanced beer.

Much more subtle than their other beers, this one employs a hop-forward nose but then a much more malt, almost marzen-like, mouthfeel.  This works well and could be enjoyed by anyone accustomed to the more standard microbrew.
Aroma has bread, caramel, and grass and pine hops.  Flavor has starts with fruit and bread, with some earthy bitterness in the finish.  Another solid effort from a good brewery.

500ml bottle. working my way through the series of jack abby brews that shawn sent me.  thanks again... pours a deeper amber hue,  dark but still allowing for some light to pass through, and topped with a two finger creamy off-white head.. once again a fairly hop forward aroma with aspirin perfumey floral tones to begin with becoming a touch grassy while the malts biscuity malt provides an intermingling with the previously mentioned. not bad... flavors of biscuity toasted caramel malt to coincide with floral hop tones where one doesnt step on the others toes. nice interplay between the hops and the semi-sweet nature of malt.  the backend presents a mild earthy aspirin bitterness. medium bodied, bigger than the others that ive had thus far with a semi-lively level of carbonation. semi-sweet and malty through the middle and bigger body doesnt make it as quaffable than the others but still a solid offering to JAs lineup.  pretty good.
Hey a vienna cool... Taste is nicely hoppy with some dank grassy hops with light citrus.  Crackers and biscuits dominate the malt flavors with a light hint of sweetness.
A hoppy tasty malty lager, oddly dry hopped to shut, cool but one of their weaker ones

500mL Bottle, purchased at Downtown Wine & Spirits - Somerville, MA. Minty resin aroma, nipped with orange and rosemary. On the palate, this is okay. It reminds me of early attempts in the brewing world to make hoppy, bitter lager and it was kind of middling. This has a clean, but strong bitterness, but not a ton of hop flavor. The lagering is clean and crisp, but the malt has a flavor like too much Crystal malt or Special B that turns me off a little bit. Sadly, one of my less favorite Jacks Abby experiences.

fresh bottle.   pours a clear ruby red with a small  dirty white head.     aroma of.... hold on a second here.  It smells like a hoppy bock!  toasted sugar kissed herb and tangerine hops intermingeled with nuts, toasted caramel, touch of aspirin.  hops and malts mix to form a weird  piney, cherry cough syrup, toast.   leaves a dank bitter resin in the mouth.   peculiar beer.    complex to be sure, but in a strange, why is this bock so fucken hoppy kind of way.   neat. fine.

Pours a clear, deep, orange/amber color with a huge bubbly beige head that takes forever to recede. Smells of sweet bready caramel with a spicy, earthy, mineral edge to provide some balance. The flavor is quite sweet which threw me a bit until I noticed that the beer is named hopbock not hopback. Sweet caramel toffee and bready with a spicy earthy hop flavor. Medium body with a moderate level of carbonation and a sweet spicy mouthfeel. This is a nice hoppy bock style beer I really enjoyed it.

Pours clear amber-red into a Sam glass. Off-white head with excellent retention recedes leaving spider lacing. Sweet caramel and resin aromas. Medium bodied with sweet caramel turning quickly to an earthy bitterness before the lasting resin finish.
